results.title: Broadway melody of 1938
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Jack Cummings and Roy Del Ruth
results.brief_description: Robert Taylor plays Steve Raleigh, a Broadway producer who wants to put on a show called Broadway Melody. Eleanor Powell plays Sally Lee, the girl Steve loves who owns a racehorse which must win the big event to finance the show. Sensational dancing is the highlight of this musical as well as Judy Garland’s very first appearance in an MGM musical performing her first big hit - ‘Dear Mr. Gable (You Made Me Love You)’ - a superb show-stopper.

results.title: Broadcast news (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Gracie Films, James L. Brooks Films and James L. Brooks
results.brief_description: Three ambitious workaholics are set loose in a network TV newsroom where their professional and personal lives become hopelessly cross wired. Writer-director James L. Brooks is a filmmaker who is able to brilliantly combine comedy and drama with rich characters and unforgettable dialogue. His satire on the media can also be seen on ‘The Simpsons’ for which he is Executive Producer. He paints a savage, knowing, hilarious look at the television news industry and also what can happen to your personal life when your job consumes you. The performances are simply phenomenal. William Hurt gives depth to a dimbulb anchor, but Holly Hunter and Albert Brooks walk away with the movie. Cast includes Jack Nicholson (unbilled) and Joan Cusack. Music by Bill Conti.

results.title: Britannia Hospital
results.creator_credit: EMI/Parlophone, Davina Belling, Clive Parsons and Lindsay Anderson
results.brief_description: Set in a hospital awaiting a royal visit to celebrate its 500th anniversary, this film combines black humour with social criticism to expose the misuse of National Health funds. Malcolm McDowell plays a reporter who sneaks into the hospital with a video camera to capture a mad doctor’s experiments, from funds meant for socialized medicine, to create Frankenstein creatures.

results.title: Bringing Up Baby
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures and Howard Hawks
results.brief_description: Cary Grant is an absent-minded zoology professor who needs one million dollars for his nature museum. Katharine Hepburn, in her first foray into real comedy, is an heiress who is determined to get him the money, and to win his heart. However, first she must get him to drop his fiance, find his dinosaur bone which she has lost, and convince him to look after her pet leopard named Baby. An outstanding, fast-paced comedy and one of Howard Hawk’s most loved films.

results.title: Bringing out the dead
results.creator_credit: Touchstone Pictures, Paramount Pictures, Cappa, Barbara de Fina and Martin Scorsese
results.brief_description: An intense urban drama, set in Hell’s Kitchen and interpreted by many critics as an unofficial sequel to Scorsese’s iconic “Taxi driver”, “Bringing out the dead” examines one man’s crisis of conscience as he battles the furious demons that occupy his soul and the sullied streets where he works as a paramedic. Set in early 1990s, Scorsese evokes a New York awash with filth, human degradation, violence, drug abuse and amorality. Nicolas Cage puts in an incendiary performance as Frank - a man struggling to locate his compassion amid the overwhelming cruelty that rages around him. His (then wife) Patricia Arquette also puts in a fine performance as Mary Burke, the daughter of a patient Frank has brought in. Mary, a virgin/whore figure who similarly rages at the injustices and inequities of life, may save Frank - as he rescues her from drug addiction. In this redemptive tale Frank inches towards salvation - dragging the ghosts of the unsaved with him. Containing evocative religious (particularly Christian) imagery, scriptwriter Paul Schrader (Taxi driver, Raging bull, The Last temptation of Christ) continues his explorations into urban decay, morality, salvation, humanism, spirituality and violence. Adapted from the novel by Joseph Connolly.

results.title: Brilliant lies
results.brief_description: Not since ‘Disclosure’ have sexual games been so dirty. Based on David Williamson’s play of the same name it is the story of Susie O’Connor (Gia Carides), who says that from the moment she started working for him, her boss sexually harassed her. When she didn’t submit to his advances, she was sacked. She sues her boss (Anthony LaPaglia) for compensation - but he claims he never touched her and she made it all up. The challenge when watching this highly stylised movie is to determine who is telling the truth and who is telling brilliant lies.

results.title: Bright lights, big city
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Mark Rosenberg, Sydney Pollack and James Bridges
results.brief_description: When his model wife, Amanda (Phoebe Cates) leaves him, aspiring writer Jamie Conway (Michael J. Fox) plunges into a downward spiral of drugs and alcohol on the Manhattan nightclub scene, ably assisted by his sleazy, yuppie friend Allagash (Kiefer Sutherland). Providing some sort of continuity to dreary days en route to nightly excess is the tabloid story of the plight of a coma baby which parallels Jamie’s fragile existence since his mother died and Amanda left him. With the help of Allagash’s cousin (Michael J. Fox’s wife, Tracy Pollan), a persistent younger brother (Charlie Schlatter), and a well meaning colleague (Swoosie Kurtz), there may be hope for Jamie’s salvation. “Bright lights, big city” is one of Fox’s few attempts to break his comic/Mr Nice Guy persona (“Casualties of war” being another example), and did so to mixed receptions. Based on the book by Jay McInerney.

results.title: Brief encounter
results.creator_credit: Cineguild, Noel Coward and David Lean
results.brief_description: Dr. Alex Harvey (Trevor Howard) and Laura Jesson (Celia Johnson) meet at a railway station and fall in love. Married to other people in middle-class suburban England, they nevertheless maintain an acquaintanceship on her shopping trips to town which deepens into a friendship which blossoms into forbidden love. This is the original screen version of Noel Coward’s one act play, “Still Life”. Atmospherically directed by David Lean, “Brief Encounter” is an evergreen romance classic of post-war English cinema with seamless performances from the leading actors and an excellent music score borrowing heavily from Rachmaninoff. The screenplay was also written by Noel Coward.

results.title: Bridget Jones's diary [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Little Bird Ltd, Studio Canal, Working Title Films, Debra Hayward, Liza Chasin and Sharon Maguire
results.brief_description: Bridget Jones (Renee Zellweger) is 32, single, smokes too much, drinks too much, and says what is on her mind. After another disastrous New Years Eve, Bridget makes a resolution to keep a diary, lose weight, cut down on her smoking and drinking, and above all, find herself the perfect man. Her mother tries to assist her in her search for a man, setting her up with Mark Darcy (Colin Firth, in a role comparable to his performance as Mr. Darcy in ‘Pride and Prejudice’), the son of an old family friend. Unfortunately, the first man to notice the new Bridget is her boss, Daniel Cleaver (Hugh Grant), a chauvinistic womaniser with whom she starts a love affair, despite her attraction to Mark. Bridget’s confusion over her attraction to Mark, her relationship with Daniel, is complicated by her meddling and slightly eccentric friends, and the breakdown of her parent’s relationship. Based on the novel by Helen Fielding. Cast also includes Gemma Jones, Celia Imrie, Hugh Grant and Jim Broadbent.
